page.title: 13Changing Times Milton Ernest
page.content: In{1900}houses had oil lamps, candles, an inglenook fireplace with an oven, a quarry_tiled floor, a scrubbed_topped table and wooden chairs. Warming pans of red_hot coals heated beds. Water came from wells. Rainwater, collected in a barrel, was used for the family wash which was done in a copper heated by wood and coal. The closet, emptied annually, was a hole in the ground with a seat. Families with 12 children were common. Vegetables and wheat were grown by each family. In{1985}houses have electric lights, central heating, carpets, upholstered furniture, tables and chairs of polished wood, videos, televisions, stereo equipment, radios and telephones. Beds have electric blankets. Water is on tap in bathrooms which have flush toilets, and in kitchens which have washing machines and cookers. Families have 2 children.
